ud1.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhirukkhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
ud1.1:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the root of the tree of awakening on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

ud1.1:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī.
ud1.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.

ud1.1:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā rattiyā paṭhamaṃ yāmaṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṃ anulomaṃ sādhukaṃ manasākāsi:
ud1.1:1.4.eng: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion. In the first part of the night, he carefully applied the mind to dependent origination in forward order:

ud1.1:2.1.pli: “Iti imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjati, yadidaṃ—
ud1.1:2.1.eng: “When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises. That is:

ud1.1:2.2.eng: Ignorance is a requirement for choices.

ud1.1:2.3.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness.

ud1.1:2.4.eng: Consciousness is a requirement for name and form.

ud1.1:2.5.eng: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields.

ud1.1:2.6.eng: The six sense fields are requirements for contact.

ud1.1:2.7.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

ud1.1:2.8.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

ud1.1:2.9.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

ud1.1:2.10.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

ud1.1:2.11.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

ud1.1:2.12.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

ud1.1:2.13.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.”

ud1.1:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud1.1:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud1.1:4.4.eng: since he understands each thing and its cause.”

ud1.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud1.10:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud1.10:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bāhiyo dārucīriyo suppārake paṭivasati samuddatīre sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ.
ud1.10:1.3.eng: Now at that time Bāhiya of the Bark Cloth was residing by Suppāraka on the ocean shore, where he was honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ud1.10:1.3.comm: Suppāraka is modern Nallasopara near Mumbai on India’s west coast.

ud1.10:1.4.pli: Atha kho bāhiyassa dārucīriyassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
ud1.10:1.4.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

ud1.10:1.5.pli: “ye kho keci loke arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā, ahaṃ tesaṃ aññataro”ti.
ud1.10:1.5.eng: “I am one of those in the world who are perfected or on the path to perfection.”

ud1.10:2.1.pli: Atha kho bāhiyassa dārucīriyassa purāṇasālohitā devatā anukampikā atthakāmā bāhiyassa dārucīriyassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya yena bāhiyo dārucīriyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bāhiyaṃ dārucīriyaṃ etadavoca:
ud1.10:2.1.eng: Then a deity who was a former relative of Bāhiya, having sympathy and wanting what’s best for him, approached him and said:

ud1.10:2.2.pli: “neva kho tvaṃ, bāhiya, arahā, nāpi arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpanno.
ud1.10:2.2.eng: “Bāhiya, you’re not a perfected one, nor on the path to perfection.

ud1.10:2.3.pli: Sāpi te paṭipadā natthi yāya tvaṃ arahā vā assa arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpanno”ti.
ud1.10:2.3.eng: You don’t have the practice by which you might become a perfected one or one on the path to perfection.”

ud1.10:3.1.pli: “Atha ke carahi sadevake loke arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā”ti?
ud1.10:3.1.eng: “So who then are those in the world who are perfected or on the path to perfection?”

ud1.10:3.2.pli: “Atthi, bāhiya, uttaresu janapadesu sāvatthī nāma nagaraṃ.
ud1.10:3.2.eng: “In the northern lands there is a city named Sāvatthī.

ud1.10:3.3.pli: Tattha so bhagavā etarahi viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho.
ud1.10:3.3.eng: There that Blessed One is now staying, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

ud1.10:3.4.pli: So hi, bāhiya, bhagavā arahā ceva arahattāya ca dhammaṃ desetī”ti.
ud1.10:3.4.eng: He is a perfected one and teaches the Dhamma for the sake of perfection.”

ud1.10:4.1.pli: Atha kho bāhiyo dārucīriyo tāya devatāya saṃvejito tāvadeva suppārakamhā pakkāmi.
ud1.10:4.1.eng: Impelled by that deity, Bāhiya left Suppāraka right away.

ud1.10:4.2.pli: Sabbattha ekarattiparivāsena yena sāvatthī jetavanaṃ anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
ud1.10:4.2.eng: Sojourning no more than a single night in any place, he made his way to Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery in the Jeta Grove at Sāvatthī.

ud1.10:4.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū abbhokāse caṅkamanti.
ud1.10:4.3.eng: At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air.

ud1.10:4.4.pli: Atha kho bāhiyo dārucīriyo yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:

ud1.10:4.5.pli: “kahaṃ nu kho, bhante, etarahi bhagavā viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho?
ud1.10:4.5.eng: “Sirs, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?

ud1.10:4.6.pli: Dassanakāmamhā mayaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhan”ti.
ud1.10:4.6.eng: For I want to see him.”

ud1.10:4.7.eng: “He has entered an inhabited area for almsfood, Bāhiya.”

ud1.10:5.1.pli: Atha kho bāhiyo dārucīriyo taramānarūpo jetavanā nikkhamitvā sāvatthiṃ pavisitvā addasa bhagavantaṃ sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya carantaṃ pāsādikaṃ pasādanīyaṃ santindriyaṃ santamānasaṃ uttamadamathasamathamanuppattaṃ dantaṃ guttaṃ yatindriyaṃ nāgaṃ.
ud1.10:5.1.eng: Then Bāhiya rushed out of the Jeta Grove and entered Sāvatthī, where he saw the Buddha walking for alms. He was impressive and inspiring, with peaceful faculties and heart, attained to the highest self-control and serenity, like an elephant with tamed, guarded, and controlled faculties.

ud1.10:5.2.pli: Disvāna yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato pāde sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud1.10:5.2.eng: Bāhiya went up to the Buddha, bowed down with his head at the Buddha’s feet, and said,

ud1.10:5.3.pli: “desetu me, bhante, bhagavā dhammaṃ; desetu sugato dhammaṃ,
ud1.10:5.3.eng: “Sir, let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach me the Dhamma!

ud1.10:5.4.eng: That would be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”

ud1.10:5.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā bāhiyaṃ dārucīriyaṃ etadavoca:

ud1.10:5.6.pli: “akālo kho tāva, bāhiya, antaragharaṃ paviṭṭhamhā piṇḍāyā”ti.
ud1.10:5.6.eng: “It’s not the time, Bāhiya, so long as I have entered an inhabited area for almsfood.”

ud1.10:6.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho bāhiyo dārucīriyo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud1.10:6.1.eng: For a second time, Bāhiya said,

ud1.10:6.2.pli: “dujjānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhante, bhagavato vā jīvitantarāyānaṃ, mayhaṃ vā jīvitantarāyānaṃ.
ud1.10:6.2.eng: “But you never know, sir, when life is at risk, either the Buddha’s or my own.

ud1.10:6.3.eng: Let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach me the Dhamma!

ud1.10:6.4.pli: desetu sugato dhammaṃ, yaṃ mamassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
ud1.10:6.4.eng: That would be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”

ud1.10:6.5.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā bāhiyaṃ dārucīriyaṃ etadavoca:
ud1.10:6.5.eng: For a second time, the Buddha said,

ud1.10:6.6.pli: “akālo kho tāva, bāhiya, antaragharaṃ paviṭṭhamhā piṇḍāyā”ti.
ud1.10:6.6.eng: “It’s not the time, Bāhiya, so long as I have entered an inhabited area for almsfood.”

ud1.10:7.1.pli: Tatiyampi kho bāhiyo dārucīriyo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud1.10:7.1.eng: For a third time, Bāhiya said,

ud1.10:7.2.pli: “dujjānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhante, bhagavato vā jīvitantarāyānaṃ, mayhaṃ vā jīvitantarāyānaṃ.
ud1.10:7.2.eng: “But you never know, sir, when life is at risk, either the Buddha’s or my own.

ud1.10:7.3.eng: Let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach me the Dhamma!

ud1.10:7.4.pli: desetu sugato dhammaṃ, yaṃ mamassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
ud1.10:7.4.eng: That would be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”

ud1.10:8.1.eng: “In that case, Bāhiya, you should train like this:

ud1.10:8.2.pli: ‘diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattaṃ bhavissati, sute sutamattaṃ bhavissati, mute mutamattaṃ bhavissati, viññāte viññātamattaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
ud1.10:8.2.eng: ‘In the seen will be merely the seen; in the heard will be merely the heard; in the thought will be merely the thought; in the known will be merely the known.’

ud1.10:8.4.pli: Yato kho te, bāhiya, diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattaṃ bhavissati, sute sutamattaṃ bhavissati, mute mutamattaṃ bhavissati, viññāte viññātamattaṃ bhavissati,
ud1.10:8.4.eng: When you have trained in this way,

ud1.10:8.9.pli: tato tvaṃ, bāhiya, nevidha na huraṃ na ubhayamantarena.
ud1.10:8.9.eng: you won’t be in this life or the next or between the two.

ud1.10:8.10.eng: Just this is the end of suffering.”

ud1.10:9.1.pli: Atha kho bāhiyassa dārucīriyassa bhagavato imāya saṅkhittāya dhammadesanāya tāvadeva anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimucci.
ud1.10:9.1.eng: Then, due to this brief Dhamma teaching of the Buddha, Bāhiya’s mind was right away freed from defilements by not grasping.

ud1.10:10.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bāhiyaṃ dārucīriyaṃ iminā saṅkhittena ovādena ovaditvā pakkāmi.
ud1.10:10.1.eng: And when the Buddha had given Bāhiya this brief advice he left.

ud1.10:10.2.pli: Atha kho acirapakkantassa bhagavato bāhiyaṃ dārucīriyaṃ gāvī taruṇavacchā adhipatitvā jīvitā voropesi.
ud1.10:10.2.eng: But soon after the Buddha had left, a cow with a baby calf charged at Bāhiya and took his life.

ud1.10:11.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ nagaramhā nikkhamitvā addasa bāhiyaṃ dārucīriyaṃ kālaṅkataṃ;
ud1.10:11.1.eng: Then the Buddha wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he exited the city together with several mendicants and saw that Bāhiya had passed away.

ud1.10:11.3.pli: “gaṇhatha, bhikkhave, bāhiyassa dārucīriyassa sarīrakaṃ; mañcakaṃ āropetvā nīharitvā jhāpetha; thūpañcassa karotha.
ud1.10:11.3.eng: “Mendicants, pick up Bāhiya’s corpse. Having lifted it onto a cot and carried it, cremate it and build a monument.

ud1.10:11.4.eng: Mendicants, one of your spiritual companions has passed away.”

ud1.10:12.1.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā bāhiyassa dārucīriyassa sarīrakaṃ mañcakaṃ āropetvā nīharitvā jhāpetvā thūpañcassa katvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
ud1.10:12.1.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They did as the Buddha asked, then returned to the Buddha

ud1.10:12.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:

ud1.10:12.3.pli: “daḍḍhaṃ, bhante, bāhiyassa dārucīriyassa sarīraṃ, thūpo cassa kato.
ud1.10:12.3.eng: “Sir, Bāhiya’s corpse has been cremated and a monument built for him.

ud1.10:12.4.eng: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”

ud1.10:12.5.pli: “Paṇḍito, bhikkhave, bāhiyo dārucīriyo paccapādi dhammassānudhammaṃ; na ca maṃ dhammādhikaraṇaṃ vihesesi.
ud1.10:12.5.eng: “Mendicants, Bāhiya was astute. He practiced in line with the teaching, and did not trouble me about the teachings.

ud1.10:12.6.eng: Bāhiya of the Bark Cloth has become fully quenched.”

ud1.10:13.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud1.10:13.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud1.10:14.1.comm: Compare similar lines at SN 1.27:2.1; and a similar idea at Ud 8.1:3.1.

ud1.10:14.2.eng: fire and air have no footing—

ud1.10:14.3.comm: Compare Kaṭha Upaniṣad 2.2.15: “There the sun shines not, nor the moon and stars”.

ud1.10:14.4.eng: nor does the sun shed its light;

ud1.10:15.1.eng: And when a sage, a brahmin, finds understanding

ud1.10:15.4.eng: from pleasure and pain they are released.”

ud1.10:16.1.pli: Ayampi udāno vutto bhagavatā iti me sutanti.
ud1.10:16.1.eng: This too is a heartfelt saying that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.
ud1.10:16.1.comm: This tag is unique to the Udāna, and seems to be a relic of an earlier oral organization. It is virtually identical to the tag concluding each discourse of the Itivuttaka, except there we find attha instead of udāna.

ud1.2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhirukkhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
ud1.2:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the root of the tree of awakening on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

ud1.2:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī.
ud1.2:1.3.eng: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.

ud1.2:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā rattiyā majjhimaṃ yāmaṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṃ paṭilomaṃ sādhukaṃ manasākāsi:
ud1.2:1.4.eng: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion. In the second part of the night, he carefully applied the mind to dependent origination in reverse order:

ud1.2:2.1.pli: “Iti imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhati, yadidaṃ—
ud1.2:2.1.eng: “When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases. That is:

ud1.2:2.4.eng: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.

ud1.2:2.5.eng: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.

ud1.2:2.6.eng: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.

ud1.2:2.10.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

ud1.2:2.11.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

ud1.2:2.12.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

ud1.2:2.13.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

ud1.2:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud1.2:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud1.2:4.4.eng: since he’s known the end of conditions.”

ud1.3:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhirukkhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
ud1.3:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the root of the tree of awakening on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

ud1.3:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī.
ud1.3:1.3.eng: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.

ud1.3:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā rattiyā pacchimaṃ yāmaṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṃ anulomapaṭilomaṃ sādhukaṃ manasākāsi:
ud1.3:1.4.eng: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion. In the last watch, he carefully applied the mind to dependent origination in forward and reverse order:

ud1.3:2.1.pli: “Iti imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjati,
ud1.3:2.1.eng: “When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.

ud1.3:2.2.pli: imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhati; yadidaṃ—
ud1.3:2.2.eng: When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases. That is:

ud1.3:2.3.eng: Ignorance is a requirement for choices.

ud1.3:2.4.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness.

ud1.3:2.5.eng: Consciousness is a requirement for name and form.

ud1.3:2.6.eng: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields.

ud1.3:2.7.eng: The six sense fields are requirements for contact.

ud1.3:2.8.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

ud1.3:2.9.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

ud1.3:2.10.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

ud1.3:2.11.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

ud1.3:2.12.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

ud1.3:2.13.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

ud1.3:2.14.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

ud1.3:3.1.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

ud1.3:3.3.eng: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.

ud1.3:3.4.eng: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.

ud1.3:3.5.eng: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.

ud1.3:3.9.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

ud1.3:3.10.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

ud1.3:3.11.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

ud1.3:3.12.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

ud1.3:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud1.3:4.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud1.3:5.4.eng: as the sun lights up the sky.”

ud1.4:1.1.comm: This episode also appears at Kd 1:2.1.1. Sharing three distinctive terms—huṁ, brahmavāda, kāsāva—with the Chāndogya Upaniṣad, it can be read as a rebuttal of the Chāndogya’s special emphasis on the mystic power of Vedic ritual utterances (sāman).

ud1.4:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhe paṭhamābhisambuddho.
ud1.4:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

ud1.4:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī.
ud1.4:1.3.eng: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.

ud1.4:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhāsi.
ud1.4:1.4.eng: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion.

ud1.4:2.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro huṃhuṅkajātiko brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
ud1.4:2.1.eng: Then a certain brahmin, one of those who murmured the mystic syllable huṁ, huṁ, went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
ud1.4:2.1.comm: Huṁhuṅkajātiko brāhmaṇo is literally, “a brahmin of the huṁ, huṁ sort”. The significance of this is revealed in Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.13, which lists twelve mystic syllables (stobha) that are uttered during the recitation of the sāman hymn. The thirteenth and final syllable is huṁ, said to be variable and “indistinct” (anirukta). It contains the last and most closed-off of the cardinal vowels (u), which creates an indistinct mumble, reflecting the undefined nature of the primordial divinity. Its significance is underlined by the fact that it is called it the upaniṣad, the “hidden connection” (1.14). Huṁ is found fairly often in later Hindu texts, even receiving its own Hūṅkāra Tantra; occasionally we find the redoubled form as here (eg. Bṛhatkathāślokasaṁgraha 21.146). It made its way into such Tibetan texts as the Ḍākārṇava Tantra, where it is said to be recited at the end, reflecting its phonetic quality exactly as in the Upaniṣad. It is recognizable today as the final syllable in the mantra, om mani padme hum.

ud1.4:2.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud1.4:2.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side and said,

ud1.4:2.3.pli: “kittāvatā nu kho, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo hoti, katame ca pana brāhmaṇakaraṇā dhammā”ti?
ud1.4:2.3.eng: “Worthy Gotama, how do you define a brahmin? And what are the things that make one a brahmin?”

ud1.4:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud1.4:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud1.4:4.1.eng: “Any brahmin who has banished bad qualities—
ud1.4:4.1.comm: This pun is explained at MN 39:24.2.

ud1.4:4.2.eng: not murmuring the mystic syllable huṁ, unstained, self-controlled,
ud1.4:4.2.comm: “Unstained” is from kasāva, which occurs in the same sense at Chāndogya Upaniṣad 7.26.2 (mṛditakaṣāyāya).

ud1.4:4.3.eng: a complete knowledge master <j>who has completed the spiritual journey—
ud1.4:4.3.comm: The “knowledge” in vedagū is the Vedas in Brahmanism and the three knowledges in Buddhism. It is not an attested term in Brahmanical texts. | For vūsitabrahmacariyo (“completed the spiritual journey”) compare uṣitvā brahmacaryaṁ at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.2.1.

ud1.4:4.4.eng: they may legitimately proclaim the divine doctrine;
ud1.4:4.4.comm: This, the only occurrence of brahmavāda in Pali, harks back to the brahmin’s role as a reciter of the sāman. In Brahmanical texts it has the sense of “orthodox Vedic doctrine” (Atharva Veda 11.3.26a, 15.1.8a; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 14.7.3.1; Chāndogya Upaniṣad 2.24.1), comparable to the sense of Theravāda (“doctrine of the elders”). Here the Buddha, as so often, adapts the meaning to his own ends.

ud1.4:4.5.eng: who have no pretensions about anything in the world.”
ud1.4:4.5.comm: “Pretensions” renders ussadā. This line is found in the earlier Aṭṭhavagga (Snp 4.3:4.4 and note), from where I suspect it has been imported. Here it dangles as the last line of the only five-line stanza in the Udāna, following a line that is already grammatically complete (the demonstrative so answers the relative yo in the opening line). Perhaps it was added to downplay the importance of the term brahmavāda.

ud1.5:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud1.5:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud1.5:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno āyasmā ca mahākassapo āyasmā ca mahākaccāno āyasmā ca mahākoṭṭhiko āyasmā ca mahākappino āyasmā ca mahācundo āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca revato āyasmā ca nando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
ud1.5:1.3.eng: Now at that time a number of senior monks approached the Buddha—Venerables Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, Mahākassapa, Mahākaccāna, Mahākoṭṭhita, Mahākappina, Mahācunda, Anuruddha, Revata, and Nanda.
ud1.5:1.3.comm: A similar list of great disciples is found in the prelude to the Ānāpānassatisutta at MN 118:1.3. The only difference is that there the final person is Ānanda rather than Nanda. It is tempting to follow the BJT and PTS in reading Ānanda here as well, but the purpose of this sutta is to extol all these monks as “brahmins”, which the sutta itself explains as meaning “with fetters ended”, namely arahants. But at this time, Ānanda was still a stream-enterer (DN 16:5.13.2), and would only attain arahantship after the Buddha’s passing away (Kd 21:1.6.1). Nanda, on the other hand, was indeed an arahant (Ud 3.2:14.3).

ud1.5:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā te āyasmante dūratova āgacchante;
ud1.5:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw them coming off in the distance,

ud1.5:2.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro brāhmaṇajātiko bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud1.5:2.5.eng: When he said this, a certain mendicant who was brahmin by birth asked the Buddha,

ud1.5:2.6.pli: “kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, brāhmaṇo hoti, katame ca pana brāhmaṇakaraṇā dhammā”ti?
ud1.5:2.6.eng: “Sir, how do you define a brahmin? And what are the things that make one a brahmin?”

ud1.5:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud1.5:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud1.5:4.4.eng: they are the world’s true brahmins.”

ud1.6:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
ud1.6:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

ud1.6:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahākassapo pippaliguhāyaṃ viharati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
ud1.6:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying in the Pipphali cave, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

ud1.6:1.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo aparena samayena tamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhāsi.
ud1.6:1.4.eng: Then after some time he recovered from that illness.

ud1.6:1.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmato mahākassapassa tamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhitassa etadahosi:

ud1.6:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pañcamattāni devatāsatāni ussukkaṃ āpannāni honti āyasmato mahākassapassa piṇḍapātapaṭilābhāya.
ud1.6:2.1.eng: Now at that time five hundred deities were ready and eager for the chance to offer alms to Mahākassapa.

ud1.6:2.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo tāni pañcamattāni devatāsatāni paṭikkhipitvā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi—
ud1.6:2.2.eng: But Mahākasspa turned down those deities. In the morning, he robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Rājagaha for alms.

ud1.6:2.3.eng: He went to the streets of the poor, the destitute, and the embroiderers.

ud1.6:2.4.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ rājagahe piṇḍāya carantaṃ yena daliddavisikhā kapaṇavisikhā pesakāravisikhā.
ud1.6:2.4.eng: The Buddha saw him wandering for alms in the streets of the poor, the destitute, and the embroiderers.

ud1.6:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud1.6:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud1.6:4.3.eng: with defilements ended and flaws purged:

ud1.6:4.4.eng: that’s who I declare a brahmin.”

ud1.7:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā pāvāyaṃ viharati ajakalāpake cetiye, ajakalāpakassa yakkhassa bhavane.
ud1.7:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in Pāvā at the Ajakalāpaka Shrine, the haunt of the native spirit Ajakalāpaka.

ud1.7:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattandhakāratimisāyaṃ abbhokāse nisinno hoti; devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyati.
ud1.7:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while a gentle rain drizzled down.

ud1.7:1.4.pli: Atha kho ajakalāpako yakkho bhagavato bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato avidūre tikkhattuṃ “akkulo pakkulo”ti akkulapakkulikaṃ akāsi:
ud1.7:1.4.eng: Then Ajakalāpaka, wanting to make the Buddha feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, approached him, and while not far away yelled three times, “Grr! Arrgh!” Then he added,

ud1.7:1.5.eng: “Now that’s a goblin for you, ascetic!”

ud1.7:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud1.7:2.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
